prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(1-0) absorption for RXCJ0132.6-0804
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation in Band 3 for CO(1-0) againest the continuum source in an X-ray selected cluster.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We require spectral resolution to detect the narrow lines expected for individual molecular clouds (>2km/s) but the spectral coverage to ensure we detect higher velocity gas close to the central black hole (deltaV~1000km/s). Therefore we need the 1.875GHz band with the highest sampling possible.

The requested angular resolution is largely irrelevant to these observations as the source is dominated by a bright unresolved core that will dominate the signal at all baselines. We will accept observations made in any configuration.

We are making a line search for narrow (5-30km/s) but deep (tau>0.1) absorption lines in the CO(1-0) line. The other three 1.875GHz bands are included to improve our constraints on the continuum in these systems and to ensure we have the best possible measure of the phase variations during the observation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation in Band 3 for CO(1-0) againest the continuum source in an X-ray selected cluster.

The requested angular resolution is largely irrelevant to these observations as the source is dominated by a bright unresolved core that will dominate the signal at all baselines. We will accept observations made in any configuration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(1-0) absorption for NGC1275
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation in Band 3 for CO(1-0) againest the continuum source in the brightest X-ray cluster, Perseus. Note that this is an ALMA calibrator at very high declination (+41) but the shape of the beam is unimportant for these observations as the core is unresolved at these frequencies.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We require spectral resolution to detect the narrow lines expected for individual molecular clouds (>2km/s) but the spectral coverage to ensure we detect higher velocity gas close to the central black hole (deltaV~1000km/s). Therefore we need the 1.875GHz band with the highest sampling possible.

The requested angular resolution is largely irrelevant to these observations as the source is dominated by a bright unresolved core that will dominate the signal at all baselines. We will accept observations made in almost any configuration. However, the low elevation of this source means that the most compact configuration will result in significant shadowing so in this case we request more extended than C36-3.

We are making a line search for narrow (5-30km/s) but deep (tau>0.1) absorption lines in the CO(1-0) line. The other three 1.875GHz bands are included to improve our constraints on the continuum in these systems and to ensure we have the best possible measure of the phase variations during the observation.
For this very bright source we will be restricted by the accuracy of the bandpass calibration but the absorption features we are searching for will be very narrow compared to any instrumental features so we can confident that some meaningful spectrum will be extracted from this iconic source!

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(1-0) absorption for Z8276
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation in Band 3 for CO(1-0) againest the continuum source in an X-ray selected cluster.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We require spectral resolution to detect the narrow lines expected for individual molecular clouds (>2km/s) but the spectral coverage to ensure we detect higher velocity gas close to the central black hole (deltaV~1000km/s). The requested angular resolution is largely irrelevant to these observations as the source is dominated by a bright unresolved core that will dominate the signal at all baselines. We will accept observations made in any configuration.

We are making a line search for narrow (5-30km/s) but deep (tau>0.1) absorption lines in the CO(1-0) line. The other three 1.875GHz bands are included to improve our constraints on the continuum in these systems and to ensure we have the best possible measure of the phase variations during the observation.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(1-0) absorption for Cygnus-A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Observation in Band 3 for CO(1-0) againest the continuum source in the brightest local radio, Cygnus-A, that is the BCG of a rich cluster. Note that this is at very high declination (+40) but the shape of the beam is unimportant for these observations as the core is unresolved at these frequencies.
Note the radio hotspots lie close to the null of the ALMA primary beam at 110GHz so the core should dominate the signal in these observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We require spectral resolution to detect the narrow lines expected for individual molecular clouds (>2km/s) but the spectral coverage to ensure we detect higher velocity gas close to the central black hole (deltaV~1000km/s). Therefore we need the 1.875GHz band with the highest sampling possible.

The requested angular resolution is largely irrelevant to these observations as the source is dominated by a bright unresolved core that will dominate the signal at all baselines. We will accept observations made in almost any configuration. However, the low elevation of this source means that the most compact configuration will result in significant shadowing so in this case we request more extended than C36-3.

We are making a line search for narrow (5-30km/s) but deep (tau>0.1) absorption lines in the CO(1-0) line. The other three 1.875GHz bands are included to improve our constraints on the continuum in these systems and to ensure we have the best possible measure of the phase variations during the observation.
For this very bright source we will be restricted by the accuracy of the bandpass calibration but the absorption features we are searching for will be very narrow compared to any instrumental features so we can confident that some meaningful spectrum will be extracted from this iconic source!

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The properties of the cold gas found in the cores of clusters of galaxies are relatively poorly constrained. Observations of the global emission from the ensemble of cold clouds traced by CO allow us to estimate the total mass and temperature of the gas. However, without information about the size and density of individual clouds, it is not possible to unambiguously determine its contribution to the baryon budget in the cluster core and how it fuels AGN activity. We propose to obtain CO(1-0) absorption observations toward the 18 brightest mm-continuum sources in cluster cores observable with ALMA to determine the properties of a statistically meaningful sample of these clouds. The results from the poor weather observations requested will form the basis of future observations to determine the chemistry and dynamics of these clouds.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.00627.S "Driving molecular gas flows with radio bubbles in A2052's brightest cluster galaxy' PI Russell 2015.00644.S "Nuclear outflow and inflow in the strongest X-ray cool core of nearby galaxy groups" PI Fujita
